generation: Another week has flown by. I drove past the new house yesterday and noticed the front window was covered in boxes. We might receive the keys at closing, and I'm getting increasingly excited. If everything goes smoothly this week, we'll be on track for closing a week from Wednesday. I stayed up late last night, watching movies with Bethany until after 3:00am. There's been a movie marathon of sorts going on around here lately. Summer TV used to be a dead zone filled with repeats, but now there are two great new shows that have caught my attention. I've been watching them religiously for the past week. One of them, "Blow Out," has a concept that's almost laughably over-the-top, yet somehow lacks any visible gay presence. The show revolves around hairstylist Jonathan Antin, who wants to expand his incredibly popular West Hollywood salon to a second location in Beverly Hills. Normally, this wouldn't be of interest to me, but while flipping through channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan, who exudes equal parts narcissism and dullness, standing in an empty space on Rodeo Drive and proclaiming, "I'm going to build the greatest salon in the history of the world!" What a week... I've developed tendonitis in my right shoulder, just under my shoulder blade. Whenever I move my arm excessively, particularly when using a computer mouse, it's excruciating. Unfortunately, I've been on a marathon updating my website and working on other online projects, which has left me with limited mobility. I'm struggling to muster the strength to draw anything. The kindness of strangers... I attempted to do laundry today with the kids in tow and quickly realized how the simplest tasks can escalate into a chaotic ordeal. However, I also discovered the remarkable kindness of total strangers, who showed compassion for no reason other than the fact that they felt like being kind. Two issues with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. While it's true that Bush is stimulating the economy, he's doing so in an unideal manner. Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had warned as far back as 1996 about the impending threat of the rise of a 'third Islamic state' in the subcontinent. T V Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the present Governor of Uttar Pradesh, had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the Hindustan Times in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he asks, does the fact that it is now known that Rajeswar, rather than himself or Mr. Advani, wrote these warnings make them ring true? Last night in class, we delved into that week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement" and the second, "displacement." In the first chapter, Casey distinguishes that our contemporary world and culture are centered around time as the primary situating force, where phrases like "running out of time," "saving time," and "just in time" dominate our discourse. He argues that by placing place at the heart of culture, we can foster a more grounded community. (Please note that this is a rough summary, and I offer this disclaimer in case my professor or classmates happen to read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly resonated with me.

Fall 1974: I was attempting, for what felt like the thirteenth time, to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person - I hate math and have a deep-seated phobia of it. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door, only to find no one there. Great, just what I needed. I returned to my studies and just as I was finding a glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. My breakthrough vanished instantly. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs - an uninvited practical joker.

We had an outing with my bank colleagues yesterday at Guintubdan, La Carolota. For most of us, it was our first time visiting the area. We embarked on a trek to the falls, which took around 30 minutes and left us all catching our breath. However, the effort was worthwhile as we finally reached our destination. The icy cold water was invigorating, and its chilliness was palpable, making our bodies feel numb. We only stayed for less than an hour before heading to the nearby waterfalls, which required another 30-minute trek. The trip was well worth it, though, as the falls exuded a calming ambiance, and the scenery was truly breathtaking. Being surrounded by nature was almost meditative, and I felt at one with the environment. Soaking in the cold water was like communing with Mother Earth, and the combination of the chilly air and water was so soothing that it could have lulled me to sleep.

Some people are jumping to connect the dots: the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe was invited by the State Department to monitor the election. A GOP-backed voter registration effort at a naturalization ceremony in Jacksonville has sparked controversy, prompting relocation of future events. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the June 29 citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville appeared to proceed as usual, with nearly 200 people departing as new US citizens. Just before the new citizens left, an immigration official overseeing the swearing-in ceremony encouraged them to visit a nearby voter registration table, a common sight at naturalization events. However, this particular table was unusual, as it was staffed by Republican volunteers, and the party affiliation box on the registration forms had been pre-checked to automatically register new voters as Republicans. This raised suspicions among attendees, including Linda Cross, who was present to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

I found the idea of that as an offense intriguing - it could have been a viable alternative to being persecuted as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I've been somewhat hesitant to engage in certain discussions, particularly those surrounding flags, but since I initiated the topic, I suppose I should offer my thoughts. Firstly, I believe that enacting a law against flag-burning is utterly absurd. I watched Troy with my family tonight, but unfortunately, it didn't leave a lasting impression on me. Although I'm too exhausted to delve into the details, I do believe the film had potential. However, I think the filmmakers invested too much in the set design, which was indeed magnificent, and not enough in establishing a cohesive tone and theme. The story was retold, but it lacked the gripping quality that would have made it memorable. Urllink introduces the latest atom/RDF/RSS reader, Urllink PulpFiction 1.0, from Urllink Freshly Squeezed Software. This application boasts a wealth of native app features. Notably, it is not free, a topic currently sparking debate on the internet. Users can try it for 15 days before deciding whether to revert to an alternative or purchase it for $25. At its core, Magic: The Gathering is a social experience meant to be enjoyed with friends, sharing laughter, trash talk, and game-winning moments. Unfortunately, Wizards of the Coast appears to have lost sight of this. When playing with friends, you're unable to earn gold, which is a crucial aspect of the game. Gold is so vital that a daily cap has been implemented, likely to prevent the unlocking of all in-game content. However, be prepared for a lengthy and monotonous 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, with whom you can't even communicate. If you opt to play for free, expect to spend around 4 hours a day, solo, for over a month to unlock the cards.

As the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the drawbacks first. I generally dislike prequels, as they technically move the story backward rather than forward, which is a common issue with prequels. However, they do offer additional storytelling opportunities. The combat feels somewhat sloppy and lacks the sharpness that Arkham City achieved. At the time of writing this review (26/10/2013), a game-breaking bug exists that prevents the completion of a side mission, although the main storyline remains unaffected. Some gadgets are assigned to inconvenient hotkeys, requiring excessive keyboard navigation, which can disrupt combos during combat.

They essentially perfected Shadow Warrior (2013) - the boss fights are impressive, the weapons feel great, although perhaps not quite as exceptional as those in D44M, but still solid nonetheless. Enemies aren't overly resilient, provided you're not mismanaging elemental and upgrade aspects. The upgrade system is well-balanced, and once you grasp it, it's not overly tedious. The elemental mechanics and limited ammo subtly encourage the use of diverse weapons. There are numerous unique and cool weapons that remain viable throughout most of the game, a notable distinction from the 'rng' formula found in Borderlands. The music is excellent, particularly the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush's contributions.

While I personally can't recommend this game, it's not entirely terrible. The gunplay is decent, provided you have the means to purchase gun parts, which is my primary concern: the game's pay-to-win model. If I could overlook this, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and the HRV concept is excellent. I'd choose this game over any Call of Duty title, but the pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting for me. If you're comfortable with this model, then by all means, enjoy the game. However, if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, it's best to pass on this one; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been incredibly enjoyable. The save system and risk of sudden death can be frustrating at times. During my first playthrough, I lost my main character around the 10-hour mark of a 20-hour campaign, and I would have appreciated the option to reload from a previous save. To mitigate such losses, I've resorted to using a third-party mod and save tool. Additionally, the aiming reticule is somewhat small, and the zoom feature could be more powerful. Despite these issues, the game has been a blast. As someone who isn't typically a fan of zombie games, I've been drawn in by the combination of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter and beat-em-up elements. I find myself playing as often as possible, always tempted to complete just one more mission or supply run before shutting down the game.

An absolutely great strategy game. Having played every other wargame, including European Escalation and ALB, I must say this one fits in perfectly. The vast number of units is impressive, with a staggering amount available. The graphics are stunning, the sounds are great, and the overall gameplay is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is also surprisingly entertaining. However, if you think this game is 'easy' or are new to the strategy genre, be prepared to invest significant time in mastering it. Don't get discouraged by losses - you will lose many units. Just remember to plan ahead, always have anti-air and anti-tank defenses in place.

I had a strong negative bias towards this game before playing it, and I was even hesitant to buy it. The concept of the portal gun and portals seemed unusual to me, despite my fondness for science fiction. However, I was pleasantly surprised. The jokes and voice acting in this game are truly phenomenal - just amazing. While it can be a bit cheesy at times, the humor is generally well-executed. Each story character has their own distinct sense of humor, and their unique personalities shine through. The level design is also impressive. Notably, I hadn't played the first Portal game before diving into the sequel, but I plan to do so when I have the time. In fact, playing the sequel is what sparked my interest in going back to play the original.

This game is a nostalgic treat for thirty-somethings who recall watching the Transformers cartoon in the UK, if only to endure the annoying Timmy Mallet for those five precious minutes. The voice actors for iconic characters like Optimus, Megatron, and Bumblebee have returned, and their voices are instantly recognisable. The classic cartoon transformation sound effect is also present. The cell-shaded graphics are flawless and quintessentially Generation One. Beyond the nostalgic value, the game is genuinely enjoyable. The combat mechanics are exceptionally well-executed, with mid-fight transformations often being a necessity that seamlessly integrates into combos, setting it apart from High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. Another notable distinction is the emphasis on melee combat, although certain enemies, such as the Seekers, require a switch to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it briefly, but it didn't leave a lasting impression. However, I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing, due to a bug that repeatedly prompted me to accept the updated terms of service. The issue was resolved only after restarting the client. What I found more concerning was the requirement to link my Steam and Gface accounts, supposedly for DLC purposes. I fail to see the necessity of this, and the fact that it's irreversible is unsettling, as it grants a company I'm not familiar with access to my Steam information. As for the game itself, it's mediocre and clearly inspired by Call of Duty, yet somehow manages to have inferior gunplay – a surprising feat in itself.

4K at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and Neptune gear are all included - what's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo This is an excellent port and a great entry point for newcomers to the series. Just be aware that there's a significant amount of (skippable) dialogue. As usual, I recommend using a gamepad, but I personally had no issues with a keyboard and mouse setup, both of which are fully rebindable. The price is reasonable, and I wouldn't have been disappointed with a purchase. More than half of the DLC is included for free, providing plenty of content to play with. I highly recommend this game to all JRPG, anime, and visual novel fans, provided you don't mind the occasional long breaks between action sequences. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I encountered no performance issues at launch, and with the numerous patches, the game runs smoothly. In my opinion, this is a truly great and enjoyable game, despite the somewhat frustrating format where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies upon progressing through the story. I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments, which allow you to play as Batman alongside another character. The option to use a controller for most of the game, while switching to mouse and keyboard for tank combat segments, was a welcome feature. Driving the Batmobile around the free-roam city, including during APC commander chases, is quite enjoyable once you master the use of brakes to skid around corners, making navigation through the city a truly enjoyable experience.

This game is a damn fine AAA FPS shooter - that's the bottom line. It boasts impressive visuals, exceptional sound design, and outstanding gameplay - with great FPS mechanics, an engaging story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a killer soundtrack. However, it's not for the faint of heart, as some cutscenes can be quite brutal and vivid. When a game is this great, its flaws become more noticeable, and here are the ones I encountered: - The lack of SLI support is baffling; I had to put the game on hold until I upgraded my graphics card, as it struggled to run smoothly on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. Make sure you have a decent single-GPU card. - Some ridiculously small obstacles can be frustratingly unclimbable.

I am not a native English speaker, as Dutch is my native language. Please disregard any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into several categories: graphics, controls, sound, gameplay, and replayability. 

Graphics: The game features a comic-like style, with very slick graphics that avoid unnecessary details. The color schemes are nice, and this aesthetic works well for the game. The graphics can be set to 'high' without putting excessive strain on your system. I run the game on an i5 Pentium processor, with an Nvidia GeForce 710m card and 8GB of memory, and it runs smoothly (Windows 8.1).

Controls: The game can be played using either a keyboard and mouse or an Xbox controller.

I'm two hours in and utterly enthralled by this game. The humor is hilarious, and the gameplay is solid. The art design is stunning, the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting, the story and world have piqued my interest, and the puzzles are enjoyable. However, what truly sets this game apart is its comedic genius. If you're a seasoned RPG player, you'll appreciate the numerous jokes, parodies, and references that will have you laughing out loud. Even if you're new to RPGs, the game's humor is still sure to entertain. If you've played Final Fantasy 7 or X, this game is an absolute must-play – without giving too much away, I had to pause after two hours to give my cheeks a break from all the smiling and laughing. So far, it's been an absolute delight.

I apologize, but I must admit that I was disappointed with this game, despite my efforts to support free-to-play titles and indie developers. The description initially resonated with me, but the execution fell short. As a fan of puzzle and exploration games, I was surprised to find this game completely unintuitive, and even after seeking guidance, I couldn't find the gameplay enjoyable. Furthermore, the absence of a pause button, or at least one that I could find, seems like a significant oversight, particularly given the timed sequences. Unfortunately, I felt that the game was overly reliant on cutscenes, leaving me with extended periods of inactivity, waiting for the next interactive segment.

This game left me breathless - I'm still trying to process where to begin. It was stunningly beautiful, from the captivating storyline to the impressive graphics, I was completely enthralled. The narrative wasn't just a generic tale, but rather an immersive experience that made me feel like I was the protagonist, eagerly anticipating the next twist in the story. The gameplay was exceptional, and I gained valuable insights about myself, particularly my unexpected fear of heights, which was triggered by the ice caverns. My stomach was in knots throughout, but my determination to help Uncle Fred kept me going. If a DLC or sequel is in the works, I'd be the first in line to purchase it and wholeheartedly recommend it to everyone I know. A huge thank you to the entire team involved in creating this masterpiece - you've truly crafted a beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization to achieve a specific goal or 'victory'. Unlike previous games, which followed the Earth's timeline through periods such as the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age, this game takes place in the future, where you're on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I appreciate about this game is that 2K took a fresh approach and introduced new mechanics, such as the affinity system and orbital layer. However, I found that these new features could sometimes make the game feel overwhelming. One potential area for improvement is incorporating new artwork, such as more immersive environments for diplomatic interactions with other leaders.

Great game with tons of replay value and an incredibly fun zombie survival experience. It's definitely among my top 5 zombie games of all time. After investing over 60 hours, I can confidently say that this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games out there. Its design is reminiscent of a survival horror, where you must conserve ammo, treat your own wounds, and take medication when infected. The zombie animations are surprisingly natural and well-done, especially considering it's a free-to-play game. One recommendation I'd make is to play with one or two friends, but the community is extremely friendly, making it easy to make friends or chat with others via voice comms or in-game chat.

02/07/2014 - Unfortunately, I'm unable to wholeheartedly recommend or enjoy this game due to two major issues that I've encountered during my brief playtime. Firstly, the lack of Australian servers is a significant drawback, as a single red bar results in a substantial disadvantage and unbearable lag. Notably, even the offline training mode was plagued by stuttering and lag, which is perplexing. When combined with poor ping, the overall gaming experience is severely compromised. Secondly, the game is marred by excessive artifacting, affecting menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game visuals. I've never experienced this issue with my graphics card before, and I initially suspected that it might be related to my overclocking settings. However, reverting my GPU to its stock settings did not resolve the problem.

I completed this late last night. Although the story isn't particularly deep or engaging, the storytelling is what sets it apart. The atmosphere is richly detailed, and the numerous collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing it out. I gained a lot of insight into the world of Batman, which made the limited number of bosses in the game somewhat disappointing. However, there are plenty of future games that can address this issue. The combat strikes a good balance of challenge, albeit on the easier side. Leveling up Batman wasn't particularly satisfying, but upgrading and acquiring new gadgets throughout the campaign added nice new gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously inaccessible areas provided a nice sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it ranks among the best of my life. While Telltale's 'The Walking Dead' is undoubtedly sad, it pales in comparison to the emotional depth of 'To the Moon'. Never before have I felt so simultaneously depressed and fulfilled by something purely fictional. In my opinion, this masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling, with a gorgeously charming and perfect soundtrack to complement it. Although the controls can be finicky and the gameplay is not its strong suit, the story is so fantastic that I didn't care. The game's humor is also noteworthy, and it seamlessly integrates with the narrative without detracting from its distinguished nature. Furthermore, the numerous 'Doctor Who' references are a delightful bonus.

Bastion is a truly exceptional game, boasting a captivating storyline. Set in a post-calamity world, you embark on rebuilding the bastion. The game offers a considerable amount of choice, allowing you to decide what to build to gain an advantage, which weapons to wield, and what power-ups to equip them with, as well as selecting drinks that grant bonus effects. The art style and music are fantastic, with vibrant visuals that defy the notion that a post-apocalyptic world must be dull. One of the standout features is the dynamic narration, which responds to the player's actions, such as switching between weapons in the armoury, prompting the narrator to comment on the new choice.

I initially purchased this game during its early development stages, when the sole currency was spacebux and there was no 'tech tree'. This was the period when the game truly shone. At that point, all guns were equally overpowered, eliminating any balance issues; players could take each other down at any time. Furthermore, the game offered unlimited gun slots and five loadouts, allowing for greater flexibility. Given the game's claim of having 'bajillions of guns', it's surprising that players are now limited to just six weapon slots and three loadouts, with additional slots and loadouts available only through purchase. I once had an extensive collection of guns, spanning about three pages, and was brainstorming new ideas, as that's where I found the game to be the most enjoyable.

This game was a surprising gem, defying the often misleading rave reviews associated with certain products. In this case, the reviews accurately reflect the fun of this neat little game, which masterfully blends the classic 2D platformer with the MOBA genre, pulling it off with style. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't typically appreciate in other MOBA games. Initially, I had expected this preference to hold, but I decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. The outcome was pleasantly surprising, and I ended up experimenting with more characters as they were unlocked through gameplay. The art style and interface have an oddly charming quality to them. As a result, I've adopted one of the characters as my avatar and even created a wallpaper from a card set inspired by the game.

I've just started playing, but I'm already hooked on this game. With my headphones on, I can easily lose myself in the game for hours on end. It's been a while since a game has had such a profound effect on me. The music perfectly sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are flawless. I eagerly anticipate every combat encounter, and the developers have clearly optimized the combat system to near perfection. Initially, I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it's incredibly enjoyable to take down multiple fleets at once. The key to success lies in knowing when to retreat - if a battle seems overwhelming, it's best to regroup and launch a counterattack. Thanks to the developers for creating such an amazing experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has introduced significant changes to the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. Although fans of the original series may be disheartened by the transformation of their beloved character, it is undoubtedly an improvement, as evident in this new game by Ninja Theory. DmC serves as an ideal entry point for newcomers to the series, showcasing the origins of a once arrogant and cynical Dante, and chronicling his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout the game, a clear narrative arc is woven for the new Dante, rendering him a compelling character to watch. The story follows Dante as he is thrust into the corrupt world he had previously chosen to ignore.

Where do I even begin with this absolutely captivating game? Its story is undeniably charming, boasting an impressive level of detail and a delightful blend of happiness, humor, and intrigue. The game seamlessly balances its tone, shifting between serious moments and lighthearted humor with ease. The character design is exceptional, featuring a diverse cast with unique personalities and secrets waiting to be uncovered. What sets it apart from other RPGs is its refreshing approach, allowing players to progress without the need for violence – a concept rarely explored in the genre. Drawing inspiration from the beloved Earthbound, it's clear that this game is something special. The soundtrack, in particular, is outstanding, standing out as one of the best I've heard in a long time.

I'm recommending this solely because it's free, and it might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. However, personally, the game had little impact on me. Half of the story relies heavily on shock value, which failed to elicit any emotional response from me. I'm either desensitized to such tactics or the execution was too simplistic to evoke a reaction. The other half of the game attempts to portray a person's mental decline through a series of visual representations, exploring themes like obsession, hallucination, and depression. While the concept is intriguing in theory, the game's brevity – it took me only 10 minutes to complete, even with thorough reading and absorption of all available information – undermines its potential.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps aside, allowing you to take the reins. It's an incredible way to challenge your mind while still being entertaining. Although this game isn't as story-driven, it did give birth to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game and beat it when I'm feeling bored, and I love to revisit it to see what spawned a legend and what has become a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is relatively simple to explain. You utilize portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. There are two types of buttons in the game: one that you press directly and another that requires a cube to be placed on it.

If you can overlook the bugs (which I personally experienced only two of: one minor and the other quite annoying, both of which have since been resolved), and you're in the market for a space exploration game, I highly recommend this one. As most reviews focus on system specs, I'll share mine: i5 6600k (~200€), Radeon RX480 (~200€), Z170 Pro Gaming (~150€), and 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€), totaling ~650€, which falls within the medium price range. Although my rig is relatively new, I consistently achieve 60+ FPS on high settings with VSync enabled. I find it hard to believe that 90% of the comments claim to have overkill setups yet only manage 20 FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? It's been that long since an RTS game of such quality has been released. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes awfully close to surpassing my personal favorite RTS game. Combining this with a massive Risk-like grand strategy mode is the icing on the cake. I'm trying not to be overly biased, but the fact that this game allows you to transform into a dragon, supporting and commanding your troops while attacking and directing unit production and spawning, is a major draw. I've grown fond of complex RTS games like Civilization V, but those games often try to cram too many mechanics, charts, and resources into a single, convoluted game mode.

Undertale transcends the sum of its parts to create something truly remarkable. The solid retro graphics and pleasant music come together to form breathtaking and impactful moments. The script masterfully navigates a wide range of emotions, from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking and hopeful, often simultaneously, while cleverly subverting RPG tropes. Without even delving into the world, characters, story, and gameplay, there's already so much to explore. But to put it simply: if you're an RPG fan, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours to spare, play this game – it's an experience you won't regret.

I've had this game for just a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an exceptional one. The developers are highly active in the community, and their engagement is evident in the discussion forums and dev diaries. While the game's mechanics have a fairly steep learning curve, which I'm still working to master, this depth of strategy offers a multitude of ways to achieve goals and capitalize on various situations. In my opinion, the game is nearly infinitely replayable. I find myself completely absorbed in every session, regardless of how the playthrough unfolds.

Warframe is an enjoyable game for the initial few hours of play, offering an engaging experience. However, as time progresses, the game's limitations become apparent, with repetition in combat, enemies, and gameplay becoming the primary focus. A notable exception is the developers' dedication to regular updates, which often include substantial content additions, such as significant system overhauls, new warframes, and various tweaks and features. This makes Warframe suitable for casual play. Nevertheless, its ability to sustain long-term interest is questionable, unless you have a strong affinity for grinding. On the positive side, the game is free, making it worth trying out, especially if you're looking for a brief gaming fix.

This game is extremely dull. I purchased it under the impression that it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Unfortunately, it falls far short of expectations. The gameplay involves absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb even more, but the experience is marred by a lack of smoothness, unoriginal levels, and a surreal atmosphere that borders on horror. However, it's not the entertaining kind of horror, but rather a bleak and depressing one that makes you question the value of existence. The depiction of 'living' creatures, from small pets to humans, is unsettling, leaving me to wonder if the game's creators have a fascination with taxidermy.

Let me explain a few things. As someone very interested in politics, I was immediately drawn to this game when I first heard about it. I thought, 'Wow, a simulator of the road to becoming president - that sounds like a lot of fun!' Unfortunately, it didn't quite live up to my expectations. The game begins by asking you to choose a side: Republican or Democrat, with no option for an independent or third-party candidate. Although this was a bit disappointing, I remained optimistic and continued to see what the game had to offer. One aspect that deserves credit is the character customization, which, although limited, is enjoyable to experiment with. It's also amusing to have the option to wear a hat or not during a campaign - a unique touch, indeed.

My stats at the time of writing this review were: 8.6 hours to complete the game, 10 collectibles found out of 25, and zero achievements out of 15. The aspects I enjoyed were: the visuals, which were impressive until the final level (ice caves), and although the story was not exceptional, the ending (following the closing credits) somewhat redeemed the time I invested in playing the game. On the other hand, I disliked: the unimpressive visuals in the final level, the significantly increased difficulty in the last level, which made the experience frustrating due to the need for repetition to achieve success, and the overly challenging achievements, with 13 out of 15 being achieved by less than 2.1% of players.

Pros: +graphics. Cons: -bugs, particularly in the environment, can cause issues such as getting stuck or hitting invisible walls despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy. -The game holds your hand excessively, making it feel overly guided. -The AI is unintelligent. -Enemies seem to always know your location once you're spotted. -Enemies have unrealistically high accuracy, which can be frustrating, similar to the first Ghost Warrior. -The checkpoint and save systems are poorly implemented. -The story is dull and unengaging, making it hard to care about the plot. I wouldn't recommend this game unless it's heavily discounted, even then, playing it feels like a chore. Having wasted time on the first Ghost Warrior, which was equally uninteresting and a relief to finish, I'm unlikely to complete this game, and will only play it to move on to the next title in my library.

I can appreciate why others enjoy this game, but it didn't resonate with me. As a Vive owner, I'm more inclined towards room-scale experiences that utilize controllers. While the game's vast universe is initially awe-inspiring, I found its scale to be a hindrance to my overall enjoyment. The learning curve and time required to accomplish anything meaningful at the beginning were too steep for me. If I had more patience and gaming time, I might find this game compelling. However, with limited time and numerous other VR games vying for my attention, I'd rather focus on those.

Hands down, my all-time favorite first-person shooter. This game isn't for run-and-gun Rambo types. Recoil and ballistics are remarkably realistic, with single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always resulting in death, unless the shot merely grazes you. Rounds drop significantly over distance, and short, controlled bursts are necessary to stay on target. There's no infinite ammunition pool; if you constantly reload mid-magazine, you'll end up with a pouch full of partially used magazines. Endless sprinting isn't an option either, as prolonged running will leave you gasping for breath, severely impacting your aim until you've caught your breath. To steady your aim, rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a windowsill. Accuracy also suffers when standing, making it essential to adapt your shooting stance.

I'd like to start by saying that I didn't purchase EU when it first launched, instead opting to buy it on sale, which included EW. As a result, I never experienced the issues that some players claim to have had with the game. Nevertheless, I thoroughly enjoyed it, finding it to be challenging in the early stages but incredibly rewarding when executed correctly. Moving on to XCOM 2, I must say that I love the game, and it runs relatively smoothly for me on medium settings, despite my somewhat outdated hardware - a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game defaulted to high settings, resulting in some minor performance issues, but dropping it down to medium resolved the problem. I'm not sure if I'm just fortunate when it comes to avoiding game-related issues or if there's another factor at play, but many of the negative reviews seem to be coming from individuals with unrealistic expectations.

More than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the world are converging on the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF), where they will tackle pressing issues such as China's growing economic influence and Iraq's future in the wake of this Sunday's elections. Over the course of five days, the gathering will be attended by more than 20 government leaders and heads of state, including UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki. Notably, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued this year, with anti-globalisation campaigners having cancelled a planned demonstration. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, which will run concurrently with the WEF's high-profile event in Davos.

The deadline for Fiat and General Motors (GM) to resolve their dispute over a potential takeover is nearing, with the two companies having until midnight on 1 February to reach an agreement. This deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, as part of their alliance formed in 2000. However, GM, which is struggling with losses in its European operations, no longer wishes to acquire the unprofitable Fiat unit. Following reports of stalled negotiations, Fiat's shares fell 1.2% on Tuesday, after a 4% gain on Monday due to hopes of a settlement. GM is reportedly offering around $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to extricate itself from the arrangement, arguing that the deal was nullified by Fiat's decision to sell its finance arm and reduce GM's stake through a capital-raising effort. The 2000 agreement was the result of a competitive bid between GM and DaimlerChrysler to form an alliance with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticised the billions of pounds spent on the Iraq war and conflicts in the Middle East, stating that the funds could have been better utilised to alleviate poverty. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales expressed his views on BBC Radio 4 and is expected to reiterate his stance during his Christmas midnight mass. In a Christmas message, the cardinal denounced the Iraq war as a "terrible" waste of resources, echoing sentiments previously shared by the Archbishop of Canterbury. During his appearance on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day, he lamented the fact that vast sums have been spent on war, rather than being invested in initiatives to lift people out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease. The cardinal urged that 2005 should be a year of concerted effort to "make history poverty".

British stars miss out on major Oscars, as UK hopes of securing top prizes were dashed when British talent failed to win in the acting and directing categories. Despite receiving three nominations, Mike Leigh's Vera Drake was unsuccessful in securing the director or screenplay awards, and its star, Imelda Staunton, also went home empty-handed. Kate Winslet lost out to Best Actress winner Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo were unsuccessful in their bids for Best Supporting Actor awards. However, the UK's Andrea Arnold did secure a win, taking home the Short Film award for her gritty drama Wasp. Arnold, a former presenter of children's television shows Number 73 and Motormouth in the 1980s, described her win as "totally overwhelming". Wasp, which tells the story of a single mother struggling to make ends meet, beat out films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, the renowned screenwriter and producer behind the 1970s horror classic Halloween, has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film that catapulted Jamie Lee Curtis to fame as a babysitter stalked by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the film grossed over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide, setting a record for independent films at the time. Hill's collaboration with Carpenter extended to other notable projects, including Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and gradually rose through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before teaming up with Carpenter. As a trailblazing woman in film, Hill broke ground in the 1970s by taking on roles traditionally dominated by men.

Broadband is driving online expression, with fast web access encouraging more people to express themselves online, research indicates. A quarter of Britain's broadband users regularly upload content and maintain personal websites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. The report suggests that having a constant, fast connection is transforming the way people utilize the internet. Over five million UK households have adopted broadband, with this number increasing rapidly. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on internet usage habits. It discovered that more than half of broadband users log on to the web before breakfast, while one in five admitted to browsing the web in the middle of the night. More notably, the report argues, broadband is prompting people to take a more active role online.

Russian oil and gas company Yukos is set to appear in a US court on Thursday as it continues its fight for survival. The firm is currently being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax bill. In an attempt to utilize international business law to block the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas, Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US. However, the unit was sold to state-owned oil firm Rosneft for $9.4 billion, following a disrupted state auction. Yukos' lawyers now argue that the auction breached US bankruptcy law. The company and its primary shareholders have pledged to pursue any company that acquires its assets, employing all available legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site as voting gets underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs - online spaces where individuals publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but the official site experienced a temporary closure due to an overwhelming influx of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a remarkable year, with a top US dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks approximately six million blogs and reports that over 12,000 are added daily. According to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, a new blog is created every 5.8 seconds, although less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing' as the China Three Gorges Project Corp refuses to comply with a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams, according to the Chinese state press. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is proceeding with work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, reports the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale construction projects ordered to stop due to inadequate environmental checks. The Beijing News suggests that the company may opt to pay a fine instead. Furthermore, the firm has disregarded orders to cease construction at two other projects - the Three Gorges underground power plant and the Three Gorges project electrical power supply plant. To date, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have adhered to the shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points with a scrappy 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross at the near post with a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne, putting United ahead. Seven minutes later, Dunne unfortunately hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman squandered City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United seemed unlikely to secure the win needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race, with their approach play appearing laboured rather than patient, and they managed to create just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales 'must learn health lessons' from England, says new Health Minister. Dr Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the job following Jane Hutt's dismissal, acknowledged "big challenges" but maintained that the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats argued that Dr Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms Hutt defended her record, stating that waiting times and lists comprised "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi, Upper Afan Valley, and AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff desired a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." One of the major issues that had plagued Ms Hutt during her five-and-a-half-year tenure as the assembly's first Health Minister was the lengthy waiting lists in Wales.

Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has commended his team's resolute display in their 1-0 victory at Aston Villa. "That was undoubtedly our toughest away fixture of the season, and it was a thrilling match with end-to-end action and plenty of impressive passing," the Old Trafford boss noted. "We demonstrated immense character and determination, and we were resolute in our refusal to lose. I view that fixture as a significant test, one that we've successfully navigated, whereas Arsenal and Chelsea still have to come, and Villa may have some key players back by then." Ferguson also praised senior players Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who replaced the injured John O'Shea. "Roy's introduction brought a much-needed sense of composure to our midfield, a quality that he uniquely possesses.

A documentary offering a candid glimpse into the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. 'A Different Story' is set to screen in the festival's Panorama section, which takes place from 10-20 February. The film features Michael reflecting on his career and personal life, spanning his early days in Wham! to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February, joined by director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. The 93-minute documentary sees Michael discussing his Wham! days, his later career, including his high-profile legal battles with Sony, and his outspoken stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads enter the US singles chart as digital music downloads are incorporated into the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's revamped Hot 100 chart now combines data from sales of music downloads, previously tracked on a separate download chart, with physical singles sales and airplay information. Green Day's 'Boulevard of Broken Dreams' currently holds the number two spot on Billboard's pop chart and tops the digital chart. The UK singles chart is also set to include download sales later this year. In the US, digital sales are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart, and will now be merged with physical singles sales and airplay data to form the new Hot 100 chart. Additionally, Billboard's new Pop 100 chart combines airplay, digital, and physical sales, but limits its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music.

The self-declared "spam king" of the internet is seeking bankruptcy protection after being hit hard by anti-spam laws. Scott Richter, the mastermind behind OptinRealBig.com, which is responsible for sending billions of junk mail messages, has stated that lawsuits have forced the company to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. OptinRealBig.com was embroiled in several high-profile legal battles, most notably with Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. By filing for Chapter 11, the company hopes to resolve its legal issues while continuing to operate. Ranked as the world's third-largest spammer by Spamhaus, a junk mail watchdog, OptinRealBig.com was sued in December 2003 for violating anti-spam laws. The lawsuit, brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, alleged that Richter and his associates sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised internet addresses in 35 countries.

Tottenham Sporting Director Frank Arnesen has denied speculation of a rift with former coach Jacques Santini, insisting that Santini's resignation was due to personal problems rather than a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. Arnesen dismissed the claims, stating, "It is absolutely not true." He revealed that Santini had confided in him about the issue, saying, "He has spoken to me recently and said this matter is absolutely personal." Arnesen refused to elaborate on the nature of Santini's problems, which led to his departure after just 13 games in charge. "Jacques has never disclosed the exact details, but I trust him and respect his decision," he added, emphasizing the need to respect Santini's privacy.

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. Following two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to hosting England at Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will attempt to give their coach Matt Williams his first Six Nations victory when Italy visit Edinburgh, but they again struggled to convert pressure into points.

Britain's economic future will be at the forefront of Labour's election campaign, according to Chancellor Gordon Brown. Speaking after the final Cabinet meeting at No 10 before the anticipated election announcement, he stated that voters would acknowledge Labour's role in bringing stability and growth, and would continue to do so. In the meantime, the Tories have outlined their strategy to tackle "yob culture", while the Liberal Democrats have provided further details on their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury penned an open letter to the three parties, urging them to refrain from exploiting people's fears during the election campaign. He cautioned against turning the election into a competition over who can most effectively instil fear in voters regarding terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's Championships in Sheffield. The only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not participate in Sheffield are US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll. Brizzel will defend his 200m title at the British trials, while in-form James McIlroy aims to secure his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in outstanding form on the European circuit in recent weeks, establishing himself as one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter, and appears likely to secure a spot in Madrid. Meanwhile, Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg at the European Championships, with Carroll currently ranked third in the world 3000m rankings, behind Cragg who occupies the top spot.

England rugby union captain Jason Robinson is targeting dual code success over Australia on Saturday. A former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, Robinson will lead England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. Later, at 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team will face Australia in the final of the Tri-Nations tournament. "Securing victories over the Australians in both games would be a massive achievement, particularly for the league," Robinson stated. England have the opportunity to seal their third autumn international win, following successive victories over Canada and South Africa, as well as avenging June's 51-15 defeat by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, a win for Great Britain at Elland Road could end 34 years of disappointment against Australia.

Net users are being warned to avoid a scam website that claims to collect donations on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate as it utilizes an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, the DEC has no affiliation with the fake site and has reported it to the authorities. This website is the latest in a series of scams attempting to exploit the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is being circulated through a spam email with the subject line "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal," which is characterized by poor grammar and spelling typical of phishing attempts.

Iraq to Invite Phone Licence Bids. Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licences, with the aim of significantly boosting nationwide coverage over the next decade. The country's Ministry of Communications has invited bids from local, Arab, and foreign companies. The winning bidder will work in partnership with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to around 25% within 10 years. It also hopes to develop a highly visible and dynamic telecommunications sector. Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February, and a road-show for investors is planned in Amman, Jordan.

More women are taking charge of home computer security, with older individuals and women increasingly protecting their systems against malicious online attacks, a two-year study reveals. Between 2002 and 2004, the number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs against viruses, spam, and spyware rose by 11.2% annually. The study, conducted for net security firm Preventon, indicates that security messages are resonating with a diverse range of internet users. It is estimated that 40% of those buying home internet security programs are retirees, with this figure increasing by an average of 13.2% over the past three years. Notably, more retired women (53%) are purchasing security software than retired men. The research reflects shifting stereotypes and demographics among web users, as well as growing awareness of the heightened risks associated with high-speed broadband internet connections.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, a vast amount of space to fill. However, an increasing number of iPod owners are utilizing this space to store audio content created by a diverse range of producers. This phenomenon is known as "podcasting," with former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry being its most prominent advocate. Although podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, it is not necessary to own an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show produced by individuals, often from the comfort of their own homes, using a microphone, a PC, and editing software. The shows are then uploaded to the internet, allowing others to download and listen to them at no cost.

Andrea Levy, the Orange Prize winner, has secured the Whitbread Novel of the Year award for her book 'Small Island', making her the favourite to win the overall prize after surpassing Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's 'The Line of Beauty'. Geraldine McCaughrean has claimed the Children's Fiction award for the third time with 'Not the End of the World'. All category winners will proceed to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, accompanied by a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will convene on 25 January to determine the overall winner, with the announcement to be made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has positioned Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.

Yukos to pursue court action over sale. The company will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the relatively unknown firm that has acquired its primary asset. Yukos has announced plans to sue Baikal and other parties involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas, seeking $20 billion in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal's assets frozen, following the Russian government's disregard for a US court order issued last week that blocked the sale. The background and motivations of Baikal, which purchased the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, £4.8 billion) at a state-orchestrated auction on Sunday, remain unclear. Russian newspapers have alleged that Baikal has strong ties to Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts sealed their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with a 2-1 victory, thanks to two goals within the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller opened the scoring inside the first minute, heading a Jamie McAllister free kick over Colin Meldrum and into the net. McAllister himself doubled the lead when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post, effectively putting the game out of the visitors' reach. Craig Easton scored a contentious goal for Livingston after an hour, but Hearts held on for the win. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal, prompting McAllister to float a free kick into the Livingston box. Miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, Hearts doubled their advantage. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right flank, delivering a cross to the back post where McAllister timed his run perfectly to head past Meldrum.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service, allowing customers to rent massive computing power by the hour. The Sun Grid service costs users $1 per hour for processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun, equivalent to 53p. Grid computing, the latest buzz phrase, is a concept where computing capacity is viewed as a commodity on par with hardware and software. Sun draws parallels between grid computing and the evolution of electricity. According to Jonathan Schwartz, Sun's Chief Operating Officer, the system has the potential to mature similarly to utilities like electricity and water. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for just a dollar an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly Network Computing event in California.

Scotland's Justice Minister, Cathy Jamieson, has issued a stern warning to bigoted soccer fans, stating that she intends to take a tough stance by banning them from matches, effectively hitting them "where it hurts most". As part of the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism, exclusion orders are being considered as one of several measures. Jamieson commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing the issue, but emphasized that eradicating sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches remains a top priority. Her comments came ahead of the highly anticipated Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The Scottish Executive has made tackling sectarianism, long linked to certain sections of support from both clubs, a key objective. Recently, Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the matter.

UK Debut for Kevin Spacey Movie 

Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film, Beyond the Sea, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, who wrote, directed, and starred in the film, drew inspiration from the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, performs all 18 songs on the film soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri) at Headingley, Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT. The Tykes have bolstered their squad with the signings of Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Meanwhile, Saracens have made four changes, including the selection of Raphael Ibanez at hooker. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also included in the pack, with Kevin Sorrell coming in at outside centre. Following an early pitch inspection on Friday, the game at Headingley has been given the green light. The Leeds team is as follows: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

The home phone faces an uncertain future, as the fixed line phone in your home may soon become an endangered species. Research conducted by handset maker Nokia reveals that an increasing number of people are relying on their mobile phones for all their calls. According to the study, over 45 million individuals in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now exclusively use mobile phones. Although people retain their fixed line phones due to lower call charges, the majority of those surveyed believe that the future of communication lies with mobile phones. The Nokia-sponsored research found that mobile and fixed phones serve different purposes, with home phones being used for longer conversations, while mobile calls tend to be shorter, often between friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents cited cost as the primary reason for using their fixed phone, as it remains cheaper than using a mobile.

Melzer stuns Agassi as second seed Andre Agassi suffered a crushing defeat at the hands of Jurgen Melzer in the SAP Open quarter-finals. Agassi was frequently outmaneuvered by the Austrian's clever drop shots in San Jose, ultimately losing 6-3, 6-1. Defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick staged a comeback to defeat Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. However, unseeded Cyril Saulnier upset fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, and Tommy Haas overcame eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now beaten Agassi in two of their three encounters. "I had a solid game plan and executed it flawlessly," he said. "It's always challenging to face Andre. I didn't want him to dictate the game. He forces you to cover the entire court.

A cross-party group of MPs has intensified pressure on Tony Blair to reform the House of Lords by releasing a detailed proposal for change. The group has unveiled a draft bill that outlines a smaller second chamber, where 70% of its members would be elected. Since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats, MPs and peers have been unable to reach an agreement on reform. The group is confident that it can garner support for the removal of the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government had previously postponed plans to abolish the remaining hereditary peers, citing concerns that the move would be unsuccessful due to opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for consensus on reforms, and there are indications that Labour's manifesto may include proposals to alter the powers of the Lords.

Allan Scott is confident of securing a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships following a solid international debut. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning experience, and I haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. Felipe Vivancos won the event, equalling the Spanish record, while Sweden's Robert Kronberg took second place and Haiti's Dudley Dorival finished third. Although Scott won his heat in 7.64 seconds, he was slightly disappointed with his final run, which was 0.04 seconds slower.

A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a predetermined date. The unnamed woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge informs the printer that it needs refilling, even when it still contains ink. The lawsuit aims to represent all US residents who have purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer manufacturer, has declined to comment on the lawsuit. While HP ink cartridges utilize chip technology to detect low ink levels and prompt users to make a change, the suit alleges that these chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of their actual ink levels.

Virgin Radio is set to become the world's first station to offer radio broadcasts via 3G mobiles. In partnership with technology firm Sydus, the UK broadcaster will transmit on select 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website, enabling them to access the service. According to James Cridland, Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, "this innovation places radio at the forefront of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station available, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Cridland added, "this application will allow anyone, anywhere to tune into Virgin Radio using just their mobile phone.

Roxy Music to Perform at Isle of Wight Festival. Roxy Music is set to appear at the Isle of Wight Music Festival in June, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM have already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, taking place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working on new material in the studio, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year, Roxy Music achieved their first hit with 1972's "Virginia Plain," followed by other notable hits including "Street Life," "Love Is the Drug," and their 1981 cover of John Lennon's "Jealous Guy.

Captains line up for aid match as Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is among four Six Nations captains selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami also feature in the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he stated. The match will provide Woodward with an opportunity to assess some of his options before announcing his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will tour New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he added.

The comedy "Sideways" dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. The film was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne took home Best Director and Best Screenplay, sharing the latter with writing partner Jim Taylor. The movie also secured acting awards for its stars, Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. With five Oscar nominations, "Sideways" is expected to perform well at Sunday's ceremony. Now in their 20th year, the Independent Spirit Awards honor films produced outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other notable winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who won Best Actress for her portrayal of a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama "Maria Full of Grace," a role that has also earned her an Oscar nomination for Best Actress. Joshua Marston received the Best First Screenplay award for "Maria Full of Grace.

Prince Crowned 'Top Music Earner': Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, surpassing artists like Madonna and Elton John in Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer generated $56.5m (£30.4m) from concerts, album sales, and publishing royalties, largely due to his successful Musicology tour and album. He narrowly edged out Madonna, who secured second place with earnings of $54.9m (£29.5m) from her global Re-Invention tour. Meanwhile, veteran duo Simon and Garfunkel ranked 10th, with their comeback tour contributing to their earnings of $24.9m (£13.4m) last year. According to Rolling Stone, "Prince returned to centre stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness." His 2004 tour yielded $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album, Musicology.

The Tories have outlined policing plans that would see local communities elect their own area police commissioner, as unveiled by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard stated that the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities, while emphasizing that it would not supersede the position of a chief constable. The Liberal Democrats expressed concerns that the plan could allow extreme groups to control policing, whereas Labour criticized the "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. In response to the plans, Jan Berry, chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, stressed the importance of retaining operational independence. She warned, "Policing is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. These plans risk allowing those with extreme political views to dictate what happens on the ground.

At a glance: Tory health checks. The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: Immigrants coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU will be subject to health checks. Those planning to stay six months or more and originating from countries with high TB prevalence will be required to undergo a chest x-ray, with further tests if necessary. All non-EU nationals seeking to stay a year or more will be required to undergo a comprehensive medical examination, which will include tests for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test result will automatically lead to visa application rejection, while other conditions will be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

The Paris promise has rekindled Welsh hopes - is Saturday's epic encounter in the French capital the most thrilling Six Nations match in recent memory? And can Wales sustain their revival to secure a first Grand Slam since 1978? These questions are now on the minds of not only Welsh supporters but also the broader rugby community, following a dazzling display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of the three Grand Slam-winning teams of the 1970s, described it as "one of the greatest performances of the past three decades". Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer, reflected on the match as "one of the most surreal games I've ever played in". Meanwhile, a crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, succinctly observed: "There was a French half and a Welsh half.

Manchester rock band Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart with their latest release, Some Cities, entering at number one. The trio has replaced flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the summit. The album follows the success of their single Black and White Town, which peaked at number six. Meanwhile, R&B star Nelly has secured the new number one single with Over and Over, a collaboration with Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, alongside Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, (Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame, has entered the chart at number three, narrowly ahead of Girls Aloud's Wake Me Up at number four. Akon's Locked Up is at number five, while hotly-tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have scored their second chart hit at number six with Oh My God.

Mefin Davies is likely to remain with Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys, with the Wales hooker favouring his future with the English side. BBC Wales understands that the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but Davies would prefer to stay at Kingsholm. As one of the standout performers in Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, Davies has proven his worth to the Zurich Premiership side, and is expected to secure a new contract next season. His summer departure from the Celtic Warriors region had left Davies without a professional contract, forcing him to take a semi-professional deal with Neath RFC. Although he gained match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, Davies had previously expressed his disappointment with the way he was treated before his move to Gloucester.

Cabinet ministers have expressed anger over plans to utilize Whitehall funds to keep council tax bills low, a move acknowledged by Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford. In his pre-budget report on Thursday, Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets. Mr. Raynsford revealed that he had engaged in "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers regarding the plans. However, he emphasized that local governments must provide quality services without substantial council tax increases. The central government funding is part of a £1bn package aimed at assisting local authorities in England in limiting next year's council tax rises to below 5%, a crucial consideration in a likely general election year. According to Mr. Raynsford, nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in the effective operation of local authorities.

Israeli club looks to Africa for talent, with four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, set to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. As the first Arab side to compete in European competition, Bnei Sakhnin will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. Zimbabwe's national team goalkeeper, Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, contributed to Bnei Sakhnin's 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. Following a brief stint with South African club Hellenic, Murambadoro recently relocated to Israel. Bnei Sakhnin, based in Sakhnin near Haifa, won the Israeli Cup final last season and is known for promoting peace and co-operation within Israel, with a strong ethos to match.

A new report suggests that lowering the drink-drive limit could save more lives than initially thought. Research by University College London claims that reducing the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would result in 65 lives saved annually. The findings, published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, come as MPs prepare to vote on the government's Road Safety Bill, which includes changes to speeding fines but not the drink-drive limit. According to transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, who conducted the research, lowering the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on UK roads each year, compared to 2003. This reduction is estimated to save the country £119m annually. A previous estimate from a 1998 Department of Transport document suggested that such a move could save around 50 lives per year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system designed for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm^2 diode measures the energy deposited by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512×512 μm^2. Unlike traditional approaches that sense the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time required for the voltage to return to its baseline, thereby eliminating the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC fabricated in the TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality has been successfully verified in a clinical setting using a 67.5 MeV proton beam.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been demonstrated to mitigate the adverse effects of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily accept external control by a central agency is unrealistic. This paper proposes a joint routing and pricing control scheme that incentivizes AVs to adopt centrally controlled system-optimal (SO) routing by offering toll savings, while user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HDVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, and the lower level employs a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model that accounts for a mixed fleet of AVs and HDVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion.
